bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 3, 1875

div1.p: Reed describes his activities to Emilie Lawrence: French language studies, reading, and chess. He promises no card playing at her request.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 3, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
September 3rd, 75.

div1.p:
Just as I
had taken up my pen, last
evening, for the purpose of wri-
ting, I was interrupted by the
entrance of Lieutenant Tabor.
The said gentleman is one of
the most sober and dignified
officers at Willet's Point,
and being a married man, is
very little given to visiting.
In fact, this was the first
visit he had paid me, although
it is more than a month since
I arrived. I am told that he
is opposed to all such in-
nocent amusements as dan-
cing, going to theatres, card-
playing, etc. Just such a char-
acter as you most admire-
speaking of “card-playing,” re-
minds me that I have been
requested to join in the game
more than once since my
advent into Army life, but have
as often respectfully de-
clined. It was solely owing
to my promise to you that I
did not indulge. After all,
my darling, I do not regret
that you made the request,
for although I may seem
unaccommodating to others,
yet I never did derive much
pleasure from the game. Under-
stand that I would have
abandoned it with equal read-
iness, had it been one of my
dearest idols- Did I tell you
that I had begun chess-play-
ing? Dr Byrne, who is something
of a player, has kindly con-
sented to teach me. I have
played several games with
him, and if my head was only
large enough, intellectually,
I should be wonderfully
delighted with the game. As
it is, I like it. To you, it
would be especially interes-
ting, for you not only have
one of the greatest minds in
this country, but also a math-
ematical one, which, I am
told, is a great help to a
chess-player. Imagine me playing
with you and being scolded
for moving so slowly & then
losing every game! I know
it would be the case. But, never
mind, I will persevere & become
as proficient as I possibly
can. I know you'll not be so
unkind as not to permit me to
win a game occasionally.
I could but smile at your
remarks on my progress in
French. You certainly have a
better opinion of my capacity
than I had imagined, if you
think that a few months will
suffice to place me on an
equal footing with yourself-
If you only knew how very
slowing my progress is, I'm a-
fraid that you would despair
of my ever acquiring the language.
In the first place, I haven't
a teacher, which is a very
great draw-back; & then I
am studying the most
unsatisfactory grammar, imag-
inable. Add to these a very dull
head, & you'll not have much
difficulty in ascertaining my
success. My only object is
to learn just enough of the lan-
guage as not to appear too
stupid, when you begin to
teach me. What fun it will
be to conjugate the various
verbs, such as “aimer,” etc.!

To change the subject, I received
a letter from “Mr Kit” a few
days ago- He made many inqui-
ries of you and wanted a
full description of my recent
visit to Murfreesboro. Ac-
cordingly I sat down &
wrote him a most glowing ac-
count. I did not forget to tell him
that Mr Smith was most attentive
to cousin Betsy. In fact, I gave
him a most exaggerated ac-
count of that gentleman's progress;
enough to cause each sepa-
rate hair to assume a ver-
tical direction- I did not tell
him who my informer was.
It would not surprise me, if
he should leave Kansas forth-
with & seek the borders of Hest-
ford without delay. May the bra-
vest win! Do you ever hear
from Harrisonburg? If so, I
would like to know if all are
well. I presume that I will
never get another letter from
Ma. She is surely the poorest
correspondent I ever knew.
Only one letter since my arrival
here, and that a short one!
Has Mrs Vaughan returned to
Norfolk? She was at H'burg
when I last heard from home.
I have been recently reading
a book of poems by “Fitz-
Greene Halleck.” some of
his poems are very good &
contain much truth- Occasion-
ally, he falls into a mistake
which mars the beauty of his
poetry. For instance, the fol-
lowing verse, taken from his
tribute to “woman”;
“What is man's love? His vows are broke,
Even while his parting Kiss is warm;
But woman's love all change will mock,
And, like the ivy round the oak,
Cling closest in the storm.”

Surely he knew very
little of the world when he
wrote that. Perhaps it is justly
attributable to his tender years,
at the time he wrote it. Or perhaps,
the maidens, in his day, were
truer than those of to-day. If
the verse was reversed, I could
find no difficulty in subscri-
bing to it, but as it stands, I can
only regard it as a very pretty
poetical figure. This is irony!

You will pardon me for thus
abruptly terminating my letter,
as I have been tormented
for the past 24 hours with a
very severe headache & am
still suffering with it.

closer.salute:
I remain, as ever,
yours, devotedly,
